regular-body:
Here’s a complicated thought I’m trying to lay out on Tumblr before I turn myself into bed: I’ve been a bit out of sorts all day, starting with the horrible situation in Watertown, MA, but of course my comprehensive exams and the weather and everything play a part, and then I encountered my first tornado warning, which was exactly as much fun as you’d think it’d be, but.

I’ve just realized that, my mind tossing on the squally waves of today, I’ve somehow ended up talking to or at least reaching out to almost every person I’m really close to. I missed a few, obviously, because this isn’t me realizing that I was unhappy and reaching out to my friends for relief; this is me not even consciously realizing that I needed help but sidling towards it anyway. Even on a day like today, where my scurrilous mood bent me away from the world and back into myself, having people around me who understand and sympathize and care really is, I don’t know, it’s really both that it’s that important, even though I’d never acknowledge it as such, but it’s also really just that easy, that I can do it with one mind tied behind my back. I wasn’t expecting that.

This is new for me. I’m pretty used to taking care of myself, but I didn’t expect by subconscious to do it for me.

Reply: Thanks for the comments, friendly people :). sometime.*: I can only agree *grin*. dghost: Me too, on both counts! I knew I had a lot of friends – the whole period since I got to the US has been really good to me friendwise, especially December 2012. The other thing is new; I don’t know if I hadn’t noticed because I haven’t been stressed without also noticing that I’m stressed, or because that particular switch hadn’t been turned on in my head, or what. Either way, it’s a good thing!
